comments:
I hava a plugin that runs a Job (which I have configured for testing purposes)
to fail with an IStatus.ERROR (via setJobStatus in its progress monitor). The
second job that is run (and fails with an ERROR status) causes Eclipse to go
into an infinite loop reporting a NullPointerException as shown in the .log file
excerpt below. One must stop the Eclipse process (e.g. via Windows Task
Manager), closing the workspace does not stop the process.

The only workaround I've found in my code is to change all job return ERROR
status values to WARNING.

The code works correctly in 3.1M7 and fails in 3.1RC2 and RC3 (we just discovered
this today). In RC3, the NPE occurs in JobErrorDialog.refresh() because the
"dialogArea"
field is null, but the "dialog" field of the ErrorNotificationManager is not null.
Tracing throguh the logic my program executed, the key difference seems to be in
ErrorNotificationManager.openErrorDialog -- in M7 the "dialog" field was cleared
while
in RC3 it is not. Since I have no insight into the rationale for the changes, I'll
leave it to the Eclipse developers to analyze further, but this should point you to
a likely piece of code.

org.eclipse.ui.internal.progress.ErrorNotificationManager

M7


    private IStatus openErrorDialog(String title, String msg, final ErrorInfo
errorInfo) {
        IWorkbench workbench = PlatformUI.getWorkbench();

        //Abort on shutdown
        if (workbench instanceof Workbench
                && ((Workbench) workbench).isClosing())
            return Status.CANCEL_STATUS;
        dialog = new JobErrorDialog(ProgressManagerUtil.getNonModalShell(),
title, msg, errorInfo, IStatus.OK
                | IStatus.INFO | IStatus.WARNING | IStatus.ERROR);
        try {
	        dialog.open();
        } finally {
            dialog = null;
            clearAllErrors();
        }
        return Status.OK_STATUS;
    }


RC3

    private IStatus openErrorDialog(String title, String msg, final ErrorInfo
errorInfo) {
        IWorkbench workbench = PlatformUI.getWorkbench();

        //Abort on shutdown
        if (workbench instanceof Workbench
                && ((Workbench) workbench).isClosing())
            return Status.CANCEL_STATUS;
        dialog = new JobErrorDialog(ProgressManagerUtil.getNonModalShell(),
title, msg, errorInfo, IStatus.OK
                | IStatus.INFO | IStatus.WARNING | IStatus.ERROR);
        
        dialog.open();
        return Status.OK_STATUS;
    }


org.eclipse.ui.internal.progress.JobErrorDialog
    void refresh() {
    	
    	if(AUTOMATED_MODE)//Nothing to refresh if we never opened it
    		return;
    	
        if (isMultipleJobErrors()) {
            if (jobListViewer == null && !dialogArea.isDisposed()) {	<==== NPE
here due to dialogArea == null
	            // The job list doesn't exist so create it.
	            setMessage(ProgressMessages.JobErrorDialog_MultipleErrorsMessage); 
	           
getShell().setText(ProgressMessages.JobErrorDialog_MultipleErrorsTitle); 
	            createJobListArea((Composite)dialogArea);
	            showDetailsArea();
            }
	        refreshJobList();
        }
        updateEnablements();
    }

Created an attachment (id=23719)
Zip file of my example

Here is the example plug-in I whipped up. It first creates 100 jobs with errors
and then 100  jobs with NPEs. In both cases the dialog caught them all.

I have managed to replicate the infinite loop by adding a throw
NullPointerException() i nthe refresh method so even if I can't replicate you
case I would like to add in the code below.

My appologies - I spent the morning trying to come up with a simple test case 
finally tracked the issue down to a coding error in my plugin -- one of my 
team created an implementation of IStatus (instead of simply extending Status) 
and defined the "matches" method as:
	public boolean matches(int severityMask) {
		return (severityMask == mStatusCode);
	}
This causes ErrorDiaglog.shouldDisplay() to always return "false", which in 
turn leads to ErrorDialog.open() never calling super.open() which ultimately 
left ErrorNotificationManager with a non-null "dialog" field 
whose "dialogArea" field was null.

You can duplicate my original observation by setting a breakpoint in 
Status.matches() and changing the severityMask parameter value to 0. I 
verified this using code equivalent to your original test case.

Thanks very much for looking into the issue (and now having code in place that 
guards against really stupid coding errors).

I just tried build N20050622-0010 and can still duplicate the NPE loop that I 
originally reported. However, since (with your assistance) I determined that 
the issue was really a coding error in my plugin, I'm comfortable with you 
simply closing this bug report and treating it as "user error". Sorry for 
sending you on a wild chase in the closing days of the release.

This won't be in until build 20050623 - you can load the workbench from HEAD to
try it out. And thanks for letting us know - if this sort of thing is possible
we want to be protected.

I verified that in build 20050623-0010 I can no longer duplicate the problem 
and believe that this is fix is fine, especially considering the 3.1 release 
date.

A "side effect" of the fix appears to be that once IStatus.matches() returns 
false (see my comment 7 for how this happened originally and how to reproduce) 
during the job termination process, NO subsequent job failure messages are 
reported, even with a "correctly coded" imlementation of IStatus.matches(). 
Since the problem is unlikely to come up in a "real-world" situation in the 
absence of a plugin coding error like mine, this is unlikely to cause much 
confusion to users, but is something to keep in mind "just in case" someone 
reports that job error completion dialogs aren't being shown...

Thanks VERY much for the quick turnaround to prevent the infinite loop in 
Eclipse and (by virture of your example) assisting me in locating my erroneous 
code.

Not sure if I should open a new defect for this or not, but I am experiencing problems with the error dialog when multiple jobs finish with errors.

I am not seeing any NPEs (because of the previous fix), but I am failing to see the error dialog.  In addition, an error icon is being displayed in the status area, but no error dialog will open when the icon is pressed.  Furthermore, any subsequent job errors fail to produce any effect within the UI (with animations turned on I can see the animation the first time a job errors).

After a bit of debugging and tracing through the code, I found a cause similar to the original, dialogArea.isDisposed() == true.  My suspicion is that the parent shell used for the error dialog is that of the jobs progress dialog (retrieved via ProgressManagerUtil.getDefaultParent()).  When the jobs progress dialog closes (upon completion of the jobs), the parent shell for the error dialog gets disposed, which causes the error dialog's shell to be disposed, which prevents the error dialog from being displayed (ever again as it turns out).

I suspect the reason you had difficulty reproducing the original error was because your jobs finished prior to the jobs progress dialog being displayed.

I'm not quite sure what an appropriate fix for this problem might be.  Perhaps a dispose listener could be registered with the parent shell used to create the error dialog.  When that shell gets disposed, close the error dialog appropriately.  (I'm guessing you can't simply close the dialog since that would also clear the errors being tracked by the dialog.)

Please let me know if you need more details.

Thanks,
Rob
Thanks for your input Rob. This sounds like a different problem - I have logged 125150 for this issue. I will close this one again so that we don't get mixed up as to what we need to fix.
